(To the Editor, " Independent.”)

We do not hold ourselves re sponsible for opinions ex pressed by correspondents.

—Yours, etc., PRO BONO PUBLICO. Merinda, via Bowen, Mays 5, 1914.

Sir,—I feel certain that you will be pleased to hear from an “ Inde pendent” reader, even though he lives at Merinda, as I myself am al-

ways pleased to hear of you when I pick up your paper on its arrival here every Tuesday and Saturday morning. I expect it is seldom you hear from Merinda, so I will give you a description of this set tlement. It is situated on the Don water-course at the Alligator Lagoon. It is six miles from Bowen, on the Ayr line. The works kill about 130 head per day. The manager, O. J. Marshall, is a good sort, and they tell me he is a N.S. Wales native. The chief en gineer, T. G. Jackson, is not a bad sort,'and I would-take him to be a Rockhampton native. The firm, I think, is Houlder Bros., and I pro mise you that if they are in any way connected with the owners of the Grange line of steamers they are pretty tight. Taking everything into consideration, every person on the settlement, from boss, to gutty men. are very friendly. . The settlement possesses two stores, one pub, large school build ings, and last, but not least, an up to-date police station. The school buildings are very large and notice able. You must take into consider ation that a few years ago the slack seasons! were very long here, and outdoor work very scarce. Like every small place Merinda possesses its cliques, and our clique is confined to the Butchers' Union, or what I would call the Cookies’ Trust, for, Mr Editor, it is nothing else, and mark you, when Mr An drew Fisher comes along he will i find them not with him, but Cooked, {They run everything but the pub, , and they don’t want that—not that I they are to be blamed on that ac count. Still, I consider they ought | to sticz up more for their fellow |.man, even if he is only a yard lab ourer. As 1 said before, we have a. pub in the settlement, and Bung is about the most independent chap in | the place. Such is due to the fact | that Bowen is six miles away, and I if you don’t like his beer—well, you can go to Bowen and get other. I Now, Mr Editor, I have a com plaint to make, and being a North erner, I don’t mind a few Sydney ites coming here and taking away the pickings, both from the butch ers! floor and the gut department. Still, I must object to nsn like them, drawing between £4 and £6 10s a week, banging on to the lot and trying to start a football club at our expense, or, rather, the expense of (he married people of Merinda. Then, again, do you think mean ness tends to- uplift the cause of unionism, for all these men are young, able-bodied: single men, who | come from the South, They want I a football club. They begged, I -cadged, and bullied last year, and the late publican gave them a foot ball for nothing. What do we find this year ? That they, the great Southern mashers are condescend ing enough to allow their lady sym pathisers to go from bouse to house asking or begging a pound of but ter, cake, tea, sugar, or biscuits, etc, for the spread to be given at the footballers’ dance to be held in the School of Arts at Merinda-on pay nlgbt. Mlndyou, even the

person who has been kitid enough to > subscribe expect ed to pay his or her 1/6 at the door as admission tn that-dance, f " nuld very much iiki. jon 10 publich the foregoing, tnt that I .rn very much hurl, but more particularly to allow my fellow-workers to see the class "f Rocks pushes we get from the South—men who, if they had any manhood in . them, would never stoop so low as fo allow canvassers to go, to their fellow-worKers’ huts (they are nothing else) and beg the wherewithal to spread at a dance so that they may raise the wind to start a football club. I would not object to such so much if they were in need, but considering that these same gentlemen can dress in the latest, pay about ls/6per week for their'"food, and live in tents for cheapness' sake, and drink beer when they attend football meetings held in pubs, I fancy that they could well afford to do without the few pence collected from the married workmen who have wives and fami lies to Keep,

To BUWKN It IYER RACES BY MOTOR CAR.

On Wednesday morning last Messrs J. Blaine, J. T. Payne, J. W. Kirby, and W. H. Darwon left town,for Bowen River in Mr Me-

Briar’s fine Overland Motor Car, driven by the owner. When such a trip-was first mooted it was the opinion of many that the oar would never reach its destination and wagers were made on the re sult. Among the doubtful ones were the coach drivers who knew the bad state of the road for such an undertaking. Indications oi the previous night pointed to wet weather light showers falling on leaving at 6 a.m. and continuing until the. sawmill was reached when the weather cleared. The little band of motor pioneers bad grave doubts as To the suooes of the trip owing to the showers that had fallen but these were dispelled after the Don River was negotiated the appearance of the weather hav ing changed for the better. Leav ing Mr Blaine’s, residence at 5.55 a.m, a good run was made to An drews’crossing of the Don which was. reached at 6.35. Here the first delay occurred, the car mak ing good headway through the sand but refusing to negotiate the water sticking right in the middip of it. Fortunately the distance to - the other side was short. A rope was got out and The four passengers whose weight ' totalled about 57 stone, attached themselves to it apd after one had missed his foot ing and came down on the stones a grand united effort by men and car had the desired effect, after a delay of I5 minutes. A good run was made from the Don to Harriets Hotel which was reached at y.50. After enjoying a substantial break fast a start was made at 8.30, the run being continuous until the Bogie range was reached where a slight delay took place on the “pinch” shoulders haying to be put to the car to assist on this really bad ascent; (road party wanted here). Eton Vale was reached pt 10 a.m., the Bogie Biver being crossed in 10 minutes with the aid of canvas and rope and a strong pull or two. After a nice run of about five miles towards Sandy Creek a sound similar to the explosion of a pea rifle bullet denoted that a tyre had blown out, a delay of 10 minutes being occasioned in putting on a new one. Another delay occurred at the'first Sandy Creek crossing through the party not being aware of a deviation in the road to avoid a large washout. After some re connoitering and loss of time the party-doubled back to the turn-off and travelled by the deviation (said to cost £350 to construct). The- second crossing of Sandy' Creek caused a little, trouble, the team having, to be again yoked up. From there on to Strathmore a fine run was experienced, that station being reached at 1.30 p.m. the sur prise of the inhabit mts, especially the aboriginals, being great, it be ing the first time that' a -horseless carriage had. travelled further than the Bpgie on this road. After re galing the inner man a start was made at 2.30 for the Bowen River which was reached in good time, and a halt -made in, the bed 7 the large sand banks appearing very formidable objects. Not being able to obtain horses to assist the car over the river bipeds had to be substituted, a muster of Bowenites, who Were Camped on the opposite bank, being made. So' strong was the team that the ropes parted and the fall of Bowen’s representatives was great including as it did two local publicans', a photographer the Press, soft drinks, storekeeper, &0., &o. A few long and'strong pulls saw the car safely over the sand and away, went “Mao” as pleased as punch, up the steep grade on the other side-without a halt. - The distance to Harris’s Hotel, by cyclometer, was 23 miles . and to Strathmore .63'#. 1 miles. Independent of the several worxing Shifts at the differ ent watercourses the trip was a very 'pleasant one, the oar being a toy in the'clever hands of Mr Mc- Briar and only ah expert cohid handle it so successfully over - bush roads that were never meant for such vehicles. The presence of the.Car at the Races was a novelty and was _ greatly appreciated, the owner being kept busy for two days running passengers to and from the racecourse and along the road to Gap Creek By the aid of Mr W Lynch, who assisted to get the oar over with a couple of horses, a start was made on'' the return journey on Friday at sundown and the run made to Strathmore; after lea’l Leaving Strathmore at 6-30 on Saturday morning Table Top was reached at 7-17 and the BOgie 8- the car negotiating the' river in fine style in minutes. The Top’ of the range was reached at 9- and Harris’s Hotel at Notwithstanding Hhe early hour Mrs Harris had a splendid dinner prepared for the motorists which they thoroughly enjoyed, making another start at TO-5O a m. A good run was made to the 2-miie creek, where a fine mob of Havilah fats was passed and here the most serious delay of the. trip was met with, there being a large amount of drift sand washed on the Bowen side of the cutting After much manoevering and some hard graft the motor was landed on the top of the bank,- half-an-hour being lost in the operation The “butter road” being very rough slow pro gress was made to Pott’s corner but from there to the river “Mao” opened the throttle and the ear

fairly flew to the Don which was crossed without a stoppage and the run continued right into town which was reached at r-15 p m The dis> tehees' from Strathmore gate were— Sandy Creek 18#: miles, * Bogie River 25# miles' Rosebank Creek 35 miles, Harris’s 41 miles, Bowen 6.6# miles The gentlemen who made the trip are loud in their praises of Mr Mcßriar’s ability as a driver and are of the opinion' that with a little attention to the roads' motoring to ;the Bowen River; would not be a very tough proposition

THE EUROPEAN CRISIS.

ON the eve of the great upheave al that threatens Europe it may he interesting to show the relative strength of the opposing forces and

to illustrate the stupendous mag nitude ofthe impending, war.' On a wa'r footing i'and . incluslve of all her 'reserves; Austrik-Hungaiy j can i bring in held S'jiO.OOQ-lneuv'' ThSatmies dfthetwoother' mem beta of the Triplice, Germany and Italy, are '4,350,000 3,380,000 respectively making a total of 11.440.000 men. The ‘‘entente" as far as Russia and France ara concerned, gives the former 5,000,000 and France 4,500,000 men and. Great Britain is responsible for 150.000 if France is, attacked. To’ these must be .added 500,000 men contributed by Servia, bringing up the; total to 10,000,000. This is over a million short of the Triplice, but in all probability Roumania Will be brought in the conflict when the numbers will 'come closer together. Onthe other hand the naval strength of. the ‘ ‘entente’ ’ is almost double that of the triplice. In battleships Great' Britain ac counts for 4 2 France 21 and Russia for 9. The latter has also 6 cruis*- - ers and Great Britain 9, showing a total of 72 battleships and 14 cruis ers as against the combined fleets of Germany, Austria .and Italy" com posed of 37 battleships and 7 cruis ers. -Moreover in submarines France and England are over whelmingly superior to the other nations., As regards the sinews of War the "entente” again has much larger reserves of gold and silver Russia and France hold in gold and silver about and Great.Britain another j£100;00o, 000 while the Triple Alliance is report ed tc .have only 21,i44,000 avail] able ■ for" war . purposes. The correctness however of these last figures appears somewhat 'doubtful. The strategic weakness of St Peters burg, which can be attacked both by sea and by laud, is counterbal ance by the fact that a blockade of the North Sea would starve Ger many in two or three weeks, so that an attack upou Russia must at the same time mean a desperate effort to keep the western sea route open. Notwithstanding the declaration made by Austria that no territorial demand will be made from. Servia and that the war is merely waged in the t interest of, justice and morality there is little to be hoped from such stereotyped pronounce ments and although some of the English and continental papers still profess to think that the war may be circumscribed the general 'tone of the European press is very pessi mistic. Moreover the sincerity of Austrias' declaration is seriously discounted by the discovery that the recall of reservists was decided upon before the double assasination which is the ostensible cause of- her attack upon Servia. It will be seen in our cables that in Johannesburg an official proclamation, calling j upon the Austro-Hungarian reserv ists to return to the ranks, bears the imprint of the Imperial Printer in. Vienna and must be over a month old. In 1909 Austria, with-! out warning, seized . Herzegovina while Russia was concentrating all her available forces in the far East and Russia is determined not to be caught napping again.
